name: Mechanical Traps
description: Physical traps using mechanical components like pressure plates, trip wires, springs, and weighted objects to harm or hinder intruders
trigger: Varies by trap - pressure plates, trip wires, improper key usage, opening locks incorrectly

damage.type: bludgeoning, piercing, poison, or other physical damage

trapComponents.severity: Nuisance or Deadly for characters of certain levels
trapComponents.trigger: What activates the trap (pressure plate, trip wire, improper action)
trapComponents.duration: How long effect lasts, whether trap resets
trapComponents.detectAndDisarm: DC and method for finding and disabling trap
trapComponents.scaling: How trap scales for higher character levels

exampleTraps.name: Collapsing Roof
exampleTraps.damage: 11 (2d10) Bludgeoning, DEX DC 13 save for half
exampleTraps.effect: Area becomes Difficult Terrain from rubble
exampleTraps.disarm: Cut or avoid trip wire (no check)

exampleTraps.name: Falling Net
exampleTraps.effect: Restrained condition until escape. DC 10 STR (Athletics) to escape as action
exampleTraps.disarm: Cut or avoid trip wire (no check)
exampleTraps.destroy: Net can be destroyed (see Adventuring Gear)
exampleTraps.setting: DC 13 DEX (Sleight of Hand) to set trap, 10 minutes

exampleTraps.name: Hidden Pit
exampleTraps.disarm: Wedge Iron Spike between lid and floor, or use Arcane Lock
exampleTraps.escape: Requires Climb Speed, climbing gear, or magic

exampleTraps.name: Poisoned Needle
exampleTraps.trigger: Opening lock improperly or failing to disarm
exampleTraps.damage: 5 (1d10) Poison, CON DC 11 save for half
exampleTraps.effect: Poisoned condition for 1 hour on failed save
exampleTraps.disarm: DC 15 DEX (Sleight of Hand), triggers on failure

exampleTraps.name: Spiked Pit
exampleTraps.damage: 3 (1d6) Bludgeoning from 10-foot fall + 9 (2d8) Piercing from spikes
exampleTraps.disarm: Wedge Iron Spike between lid and floor, or use Arcane Lock
exampleTraps.escape: Requires Climb Speed, climbing gear, or magic

exampleTraps.name: Poisoned Darts
exampleTraps.damage: 1d3 darts, 3 (1d6) Poison per dart, DEX DC 13 save to avoid
exampleTraps.effect: Resets at start of next turn if activated fewer than 3 times
exampleTraps.detect: DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) as Search action for wall holes
exampleTraps.disarm: Plug holes with wax/cloth, or wedge pressure plate
exampleTraps.scaling: 5-10: 7 (2d6) per dart | 11-16: 14 (4d6) per dart | 17-20: 24 (7d6) per dart

exampleTraps.name: Rolling Stone
exampleTraps.damage: 55 (10d10) Bludgeoning, DEX DC 15 save to avoid, plus Prone condition
exampleTraps.effect: 5-foot-radius stone rolls Initiative +8, moves 60 feet per turn. Stops when hits wall
exampleTraps.disarm: Wedge pressure plate with Iron Spike
exampleTraps.destroy: Large object, AC 17, HP 100, Damage Threshold 10
exampleTraps.slow: DC 20 STR (Athletics) as action reduces movement by 15 feet

detection.method: Wisdom (Perception) for visual elements, Intelligence (Investigation) for mechanisms, Study action for complex analysis

mitigation: Use Search action to detect trap components (trip wires, pressure plates)
Use Study action to analyze mechanisms and construction
Disable triggers (wedge pressure plates, cut trip wires)
Use Thieves' Tools to disarm complex mechanisms
Bypass entirely with magic (Misty Step, Spider Climb)
Have high Dexterity for saving throws
Use pole or servant to trigger traps safely
Cast spells to avoid triggers (Knock, Arcane Lock)
designPrinciples: Use traps sparingly - too many slow game down
Best traps are fleeting distractions or deadly puzzles requiring teamwork
Avoid undetectable and inescapable traps - rarely fun
Nuisance traps unlikely to seriously harm characters of indicated levels
Deadly traps can grievously damage characters of indicated levels
Scale carefully - nuisance at high level can be deadly at low level

srdReference.quote: Traps should be used sparingly, lest they lose their charm. A hidden pit can be a fun surprise, but too many traps in an adventure can lead players to become overly cautious, which slows down the game. The best traps are fleeting distractions that skilled characters can overcome in a short amount of time or deadly puzzles that require quick thinking and teamwork to overcome.
